Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

There really aren't any studies I can personally attest to since I have rea=
lly just begun this learning process myself.  I will note that it appears t=
o me based solely on observation that using just the technical bar data is =
inadequate.  This kind of reminds me of the problem faced when trying to us=
e neural networks to recognize speech.  In this instance a simple frame by =
frame fourier transform of the data will not produce the patterns necessary=
 for detection.  You actually have to analyze the spectrogram of varying ti=
me periods for those patterns to develop properly.  

It might be more usef=
ul to include standard indicators over differing time periods with other fu=
ndamental financial data, etc.  Perhaps using statistics like those used in=
 digital signal processing would be a better idea as well.  

I think the b=
iggest problem at this point is that PCs just aren't quite fast enough or a=
re limited by available RAM.  this is bound to change very quickly though s=
o developing these systems now makes a lot of sense to me.  

As far as my =
current implementation is concerned.  Bascially what I've done is developed=
 a backtesting engine which is utilized by an agent of sorts which randomly=
 selects techical indicators with varying parameters and runs them against =
the market data.  This has been marginally effective and I think this has j=
ust brought home the point to me that technical indicators alone are not en=
ough.

My current idea is to replace those algorithmic technical indicators=
 with small neural networks that I can train to act as technical indicators=
.  Not because I necessarily believe this will produce better results but b=
ecause I intend to modify my current system to handle neural networks inste=
ad of the predefined indicator classes I'm currently using.  NEAT looks lik=
e a good place to start digging into code to do this.

BTW, I'm working in =
C#.

As far as the time series data, if all you are looking for are a coupl=
e of data sets than you should definately check out finance.yahoo.com.  You=
 can download CSV files for free.  The oldest I have going back to the 1960=
's (IBM on the NYSE).

If you think you might have a need for ALL of it the=
n we can make arangements for me to transmit this to you over the internet.=
  That file which covers all historical data for all US markets compressed =
to just over 500meg using RAR.


  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Co=
lin Green 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Saturday, September 09, 2006=
 8:36 AM
  Subject: Re: [neat] Evolving a Trading Strategy: Update


  Hi J=
eff,

  Jeff Morton wrote:

  >I'd like to introduce myself since I'm basic=
ally doing the same thing you are and would like to interact with other idi=
viduals about this. I've read a significant number of published academic pa=
pers on the subject of using neural networks to forecast financial markets,=
 and it appears to me that the majority of experiments produce results whic=
h are better than chance.
  >

  I have to admit to not having read any pap=
ers on the subject for some 
  years. Largely on the basis that anyone with=
 a profitable system will 
  probably keep the details to themselves and th=
e institution/fund they 
  work for - or they may approach some fund managm=
ent company on finding a 
  good system, e.g. if it only works on a short t=
erm real time basis and 
  therefore needs expensive data feeds and other i=
nfrastructure to be useful.

  Just out of interest are there any papers in=
 particular that you would 
  suggest reading?

  > I've also read several =
news articles in recent past about these techniques being used by financial=
 institutions, but the actual information on how they work is always missin=
g. Clearly there is a natural human instinct to defend information which is=
 advantageous to survival, and I believe the evidence for this occuring her=
e is intuitively obvious.
  > 
  >

  Indeed.

  >I've been working on an a=
pplication (a toolbox of sorts) which is capable of evolving trading strate=
gies based on common technical indicators with variable time frames through=
 the use of basic genetic algorithms. I am interested in creating component=
 indicators based on simple neural networks and intend to utilize the Shapr=
NEAT code (btw, thank you to the author who ported this) to build these net=
works.
  > 
  >

  Ok perhaps you could explain in a bit more detail what y=
ou mean by 
  "component indicators based on simple neural networks"? Do yo=
u mean 
  evolving ANNs produce a technical indicator, the outputs of which=
 can 
  then be used elsewhere? Sounds a bit like modular NEAT.

  >Since y=
ou are already doing this I was wondering if you would be willing to share =
the code you've developed so far. You mentioned that you were lacking in ma=
rket data to train your networks. I've developed a simple tool to import US=
 market data from YAHOO finance if you are interested. Compressed, the data=
 is approximately 500 megs and contians the nasdaq, nyse, amex, nasdaq fund=
 market, and some of the otcbb issues. I have a tool to scan this data for =
logical anomalies and the data seems very clean. 
  > 
  >

  Yes I'd be in=
terested in some form of collaboration, about how far back 
  does your col=
lected data go? Also if you have a reasonably fast PC you 
  should be able=
 to compress that data down to a more manageable size 
  using 7zip (www.7z=
ip.org), although 500mb is fairly manageable in these 
  days of broadband.=


  Regards,

  Colin.
